  • Dawn

    ▬▬▬▬★★★★ that’s a full enjoy with waitbutwhy… ▬▬▬▬▬☛ Continue Reading

  • GMdV

    I really enjoyed this article, but I got a some remarks:

    – First of all: you haven’t divided the share of petroleum used for transportation between public and private transportation. Electric vehicles can only (barely) replace the private share, but they’re not well suited for industrial use (big rigs, planes, ships, etc…). So the potential savings from completely replacing our ICE cars with electric vehicles is half of what you are suggesting they could be.
    For those kinds of applications, fuel cells make much more sense.

    – Second of all: rare earths are an ugly beast. They are located in very few countries and most studies agree on the fact that a widespread adoption of electric vehicles woukd lead to shortages of those elements.

    -Third of all: adopting electric vehicles would only cut a small slice in the world energy consumption, which wouldn’t save us from the impending doom of running out of fossil fuels. At the time being we haven’t found a technology (apart from a widespread use of nuclear power, which has its own (huuuuge) share of problems) that can effectively replace fossil fuels as pur main energy source. I really think this is the great filter for our civilisation.

    • Tipsy

      Elon Musk disagrees with you, think everything (including jets) with go electric, except for Rockets.

      • GMdV

        Let’s assume we develop a technology that can replace fossil fuels in planes/rigs/etc… (which is really not likely to happen, electric power simply isn’t well suited for some kinds of uses. E.g. jet planes: battery power density will never be on par with that of fossil fuels, meaning that battery packs will always be way too heavy for any plane to fly. Solar powered planes are simply impractical and the advances that will be made in solar panels technology (the third generation of solar panels, those based on organic cells, quantum dots or other technologies, are won’t be available before 10/20 yrs and their real world efficiency is still unclear) will never allow a “real plane” (as in: one that can actually carry people and goods) to fly on solar power alone)

        Anyway: even if that was the case, we would still not be solving the huge problem of fossil fuels RUNNING OUT.
        Electric vehicles are actually nothing more than a stopgap, and always will be, until we find a way to effectively replace fossil fuels as our main source of energy.
        And that goes along with stopping climate change, of course.

        • Tipsy

          Sorry if I trust the Rocket engineer, who says if he had the time he’d build a vertical take off and landing electric jet, over you.

          • http://twitter.com/markusvonroder Markus Roder

            To be fair, even Elon says (watch his MIT talk) that his electric VTOL plane would rely heavily on computer control (via getting rid of ailerons, elevators, rudders and such, and replace them with gimbaling engines), would not be able to glide, and would have a way worse weight/cargo ratio.

            Oh, and that it is only possibly with batteries that are > 400 Wh/kg.

            • Tipsy

              You’d wanna hope they’re reliable as fuck if they wont glide.

            • http://twitter.com/markusvonroder Markus Roder

              Indeed.

        • JoSCh0001

          I remember reading 10, even 5 years ago guys talking about how electric cars won’t have reasonable ranges or even above 100 miles for decades. I suspect that those same guys are very worried about rare earths, big rigs, planes, etc.

          • GMdV

            Potential rare earths shortages are confirmed by many scientific studies on the matter.
            Still, you are missing the point of what I’m saying: going electric won’t save the world until we find a viable alternative to fossil fuels as our primary energy source.

            • JoSCh0001

              There are a bunch of technologies in the hopper, and many that are already viable and getting better every day. Solar, wind, nuclear, biofuels, synthetic “rare earths” etc. I guess some people are optimistic after reading something like this and others just… aren’t.

            • GMdV

              Or maybe there are people who just got their degree in energy engineering and spent the past five years studying the actual state and future developments of all these technologies and the answer they got from all this is: at the moment we’re pretty much fucked.

              Except maybe for nuclear fusion. That might work, in the very long term.

    • Ryder

      OMG… puleeze. We’re NEVER going to run out of fossil fuels. Ever. How did this myth ever get started?

      And nuclear has no more or less problems than anything else, they are just of a different nature. Nuclear is, so far, proving to be the SAFEST form of energy, in terms of fatalities… even better than wind and solar. We were *sold* on irrational fears… marketers of the great nuclear apocalypse cemented this fear into our culture, and we’ve never really recovered.

      How do we know? We can see it.

      When the tsunami hit the west coast of Japan… a *real* disaster with tens of thousands of lives lost… entire cities removed from the face of the earth… the media did what? They focused on the Fukushima power plants… with a radiation death toll of exactly zero.

      This is the result of irrational FEAR. Piles of bodies ignored… and instead wide-eyed focus on the tick of a Geiger counter… because they don’t understand it… and remember Godzilla movies from their childhood, no doubt.

    • http://twitter.com/markusvonroder Markus Roder

      Widespread use of nuclear power does not have a “huuuuuge” share of problems. Please read up on your Barry Brook, mmmkay?

      • GMdV

        Chernobyl? (Human mistake)
        Fukushima? (Natural disaster)
        The radioactive wastes that have to be isolated for thousands years?
        How are these not huge problems?
        Alright, breeder reactors produce very little wastes, but they still need thousands of years before they decay into less radioactive forms.
        Plus there’s a huge problem of acceptance in our society. Common people are scared of nuclear power, my country, for example, voted to ban nuclear powerplants after Chernobyl happened.

        • http://twitter.com/markusvonroder Markus Roder

          Even the current share of problems you mention is not “huge”, and as you state yourself, all are solvable by deploying nuclear technology that is already developed.

          Chernobyl took, depending on how you count, between 34 and 3000 lives.

          Fukushima took none, by any measure.

          All in all, Nuclear has the lowest death count per Terawatthour of energy produced, by a LOOOOONG margin: http://nextbigfuture.com/2011/03/deaths-per-twh-by-energy-source.html.

          Yup, that’s even lower than solar and wind.

          Radioactive waste does not have to be isolated for thousands of years. It SHOULD, but even if simply “detained” for just a few decades, its dangerousness is not even comparable to the NOT-AT-ALL-decaying poisons freed by burning fossil fuels.

          As you mention yourself, breeder reactors (and even better, IFRs or LFTRs) can get rid of the current crop of “spent” fuel (which really still contains almost 99% of its original potential energy).

          As for acceptance: Originally well-meaning, but now dangerous organisations like Greenpeace have been doing anti-scientific propaganda against nuclear. Which is ironic, because nuclear alone has the potential to save the environment in the short term. Like Elon Musk, I am also a big fan of solar, but it simply can’t be ramped up soon enough to make a meaningful impact re: replacing coal and gas.

          • GMdV

            Don’t get me wrong: I’m aware of the data’s on death count and the other datas. I’m totally pro nuclear power and I know that the propaganda against it is largely exaggerated.
            But still I’m not convinced it’s a completely viable and sustainable solution to the world’s energy need in the long ter, as in with no harm whatsoever for us and the environment.
            I mean: when a nuclear disaster strikes, it strikes hard.
            Also I can’t seem to find the projections on uranium availability, but even that is poised to finish, eventually, isn’t it?

            There’s another thing I was actually thinking of, today, but it’s more of a personal doubt than anything else. Since nuclear power is not suited for variable loads, is a power grid solely based on nuclear power for the base load and other renewables for the peak loads sustainable?

            • http://twitter.com/markusvonroder Markus Roder

              With LFTRs an IFRs, we have nuclear fuel for hundreds of years from the current “nuclear waste”- that way, we can kill two birds with one stone.

              Even longer Term, we can go to Uranium from seawater and/or Thorium from “fresh mining” – thorium is actually quite plentiful. Personally, I think we should “save up” the Uranium, as reactors for starships are probably easier to build with Uranium / Plutonium as fuel ;).

              No harm whatsoever – you are clearly right, that is not possible. But neither is “no harm whatsoever” possible with any other form of energy generation. A denser energy is probably best for generating the least amount of damage per unit of energy generated.

              As for the variable load question: Correct, but I see the grid going to basically a caseload function anyway – peaks will most likely be shaved off by on-site generation at the point of consumption.

            • Headless Unicorn Guy

              Another legacy of the Cold War Nuclear Arms Race — a lot of American and Russian nuke plants were built primarily to breed plutonium (reprocessed from spent fuel) for bombs; the Atoms for Peace power generation was a public sideline.

            • Headless Unicorn Guy

              Legacy of the Cold War, where NUCLEAR mean Nuclear War and the KGB bankrolled Western peace and anti-nuke movements as part of a Hearts & Minds strategy. The USSR and Cold War are gone, but the momentum (and True Believers with The Cause) remains.

  • http://radical-moderation.blogspot.com/ TheRadicalModerate

    The “canopy” metaphor of innovation is worth the time spent reading this all by itself. Very nice job. Now go put your carpal-tunnel splints on.

    One quibble:

    “You could replace 70% of US gas car miles with EV miles with no changes to the grid.”

    I’d like to see your sources and math on that one. I suspect that you could do a 70% replacement and not exceed peak current capacity, but then what would you do when the rest of the things that require peaking today (e.g. air conditioners) were switched on? I understand the “charge during off-peak hours” argument, but that’s only going to go so far. If you’ve got 70% EV penetration, some fraction of those are going to need on-peak charging.

    I agree that rooftop solar helps a lot in this area, but in some sense it’s in a race with EV adoption. If rooftop solar installation rates are high enough, then the changes to the grid are mostly at the end of the pole for electricity sell-backs, and that scales pretty smoothly. (At the worst, you don’t get to sell back your excess energy, but you still get your Model 3 charged in the garage, and you can do desperate hand-to-hand zombie-stabbing in air-conditioned comfort.) On the other hand, if the EV adoption swamps the rooftop roll-out, then the changes to the grid are for additional peaking and transmission capacity, and that’s a large-scale infrastructure change.

    Hopefully you’re going to do a maxi-post on Elon’s vision of how the grid evolves. If/when you do, I hope you’ll spend some time on energy density. I think that renewables (esp. wind) may be able to be jiggered to deal with the current industrial demands, but I’d expect us to invent some new technologies that require extremely large, extremely dense energy sources in the future. Continental-scale water desalination tops my list, but eventually I’m going to get pouty if I can’t have my antimatter spaceship.

    • NorwegianThirtySomething

      In Norway, there have been calculations done that if absolutely all personal transportation (cars) was electric instead of fossil-fuel driven, the reuired electricity would be 5% of our country’s total output.

      And that’s without factoring in the lessened need to power refineries. And those babies gobble the gigawatts, baby…

      • jeffhre

        Wow! In any case, without refineries, the peaks would all be replaced with completely different consumption curves.

      • http://radical-moderation.blogspot.com/ TheRadicalModerate

        OK, you’ve goaded me into taking a stab at this quantitatively. Not a very exhaustive stab, but a stab. I don’t think I’m going to do Norway, since it’s only got a population a little bigger than Alabama and doesn’t get hot in the summer.

        Here we go:

        1) 70% EV car passenger-mile penetration. In 2013, that would have been 2.0 trillion passenger miles. Driving a bit less than 6 days a week, that gives about 6.4B passenger-miles per day.

        2) An EV can do 3 mi/kWh.

        3) It turns out that there’s no such thing as a “load curve for the entire US”. So, instead, I’m going to use the New York Independent System Operator, because it happens to be an ISO that serves exactly everyone in New York, and it publishes hourly load stats. The highest load in late July 2014, was on July 23. Here are the hourly numbers, in MW:

        Time MW delta-peak
        00:00 18,626 08,676
        01:00 17,823 09,479
        02:00 17,356 09,946
        03:00 17,043 10,259
        04:00 16,984 10,318
        05:00 17,452 09,850
        06:00 18,706 08,596
        07:00 20,615 06,687
        08:00 22,298 05,004
        09:00 23,637 03,665
        10:00 24,767 02,535
        11:00 25,594 01,708
        12:00 26,198 01,104
        13:00 26,753 00,549
        14:00 27,101 00,201
        15:00 27,213 00,089
        16:00 27,302 00,000
        17:00 27,144 00,158
        18:00 26,371 00,931
        19:00 25,425 01,877
        20:00 24,722 02,580
        21:00 24,182 03,120
        22:00 22,685 04,617
        23:00 20,821 06,481

        The peak 1-hour load was between 16:00 and 17:00, and averaged 27,302 MW, while the minimum load was between 04:00 and 05:00 and averaged 16,984 MW. We can make the (iffy) assumption that we can get “unused capacity” but subtracting the load for any hour from the peak load. Note that late July is about as hot as it gets, and ought to run the system at something close to what the ISO considers safe capacity. (Almost everybody adds adds a 20% margin onto their annual peak load, but charging EVs isn’t going to make them change their minds about that. The consequences of falling short are fairly catastrophic.)

        4) New York’s a nice big state. (I would have used California or Texas, but California doesn’t publish hourly numbers and the ERCOT ISO isn’t exactly contiguous with Texas.) However, while It had 6.2% of the US population in July 2014, it only had 4.6% of the cars, so let’s take 4.6% of our 6.4B passenger-miles, giving us 294M passenger-miles.

        5) Let’s now assume that 85% of those passenger miles (250M) are represented by people who come home exactly at 18:00 and plug their EV into the wall, and expect it to be ready to go the next morning at 07:00. (Note that forgetting to plug in your EV is probably a bit of a career-limiting move, so people are going to get into the habit of plugging the car into the wall before they go into the house to kiss the spouse and kids.)

        6) 250M passenger miles @ 3 mi/kWh = 83M kWh = 83,000 MWh. That’s what we have to deliver over the 13 hours between 18:00 and 07:00. Can we do it? If we add up that “unused” peaking column, it comes out to 108K MWh of energy, so we’re probably OK. Note that we’re not wildly OK, and states with a higher number of per-capita passenger miles could be in mild trouble. But we’re in the ballpark.

        7) But wait! We’re assuming no grid changes, so the chargers are probably sucking down power as fast as they can once they’re plugged in. The standard Tesla Model S charger pulls 10 kW. If we also assume that 70% of the cars in New York are EVs, we get 85% of 70% of 5.1M cars @ 10 kW = 30,500 MW, all plugged in right on the dot of 18:00. Since we only have 931 MW of unused capacity at 18:00…

        8) Hello darkness, my old friend.

        So: chargers have to be smart enough not to hurt the grid, which requires a rudimentary “smart grid” at the very least. The smart grid would let the EV tell it it needed to charge and the grid would then compute the number of cars charging and tell them all how fast they could charge. But this is some non-trivial infrastructure.

        The other issue here is that we’re assuming we’re charging EVs with peaking plants. Peaking plants are expensive power. A cheaper way to go would be to add more baseload power. But again, that’s a grid change.

        On the other hand, if everybody has a 10 kWh Tesla Powerwall hanging in their garage and a bunch of solar panels on their roof, maybe that’s enough energy stored over the day to shift the point where we start drawing from the grid from 18:00 to, say, 20:00, at which point… we still don’t have enough unused capacity to pull off the rest of the 30,500 MW load.

        I would rate the statement that “the grid has enough capacity to handle 70% of the passenger miles” today as requiring large number of caveats, at best. You either need a genuine smart grid or a buttload of solar and battery storage.

        • Ivan

          Your Math seem’s to be SOLID! – But in real life, I would say half or even less of the cars will have to fill from ZERO to 250 miles each day. Witch means, 50% (pure guess on my end) cars would not start from ZERO – but let’s say from 150 miles already. I dont have any source on this, but some friends who have EV’s – they almost never charge from ZERO.

          • http://radical-moderation.blogspot.com/ TheRadicalModerate

            I’m more worried about the coming-home-from-work peak, even if it’s only 10-20 kWh total, than I am about the full overnight load. Somebody up-thread (see tech01xpert’s comment here) confirmed that most of the chargers do have scheduling features on them, so you plug it in at 18:00 but the charge doesn’t start until midnight, for example. If people actually use that feature, that would help enormously. However, if they’re their usual gadget-impaired selves, there could be a problem.

            If the chargers phone home with sufficiently precise geoloc information, and the charger companies’ servers are sufficiently wired into all of the local utilities to distribute load heuristically (as opposed to with direct feedback from the power company), and the end-user isn’t so paranoid that he/she is willing to wait overnight for a charge, and the default mode for the charger is to load-distribute, then it looks like something close to 70% EV passenger-miles is possible.

            • jeffhre

              A lot of ifs…

          • jeffhre

            80% of driving in the US is 37 miles per day or less according to EPA stats. Check this by multiplying the amounts by 365! For 250 miles per day I get 91,250 miles of driving per year, a bit higher that the 13,000 miles or so a year average often quoted by news media. I believe EU averages are lower than the US.

            • Headless Unicorn Guy

              And don’t forget the difference between Eastern & Western US. Driving conditions & distances are very different.

              Eastern US (and Great Lakes area) were settled first; many of the major cities were laid out in the 19th Century when rail was the only large-scale transportation. As a result, they are less car-dependent.

              (op cit tale about a NY Congressman once trying to outlaw private cars with the comment “They can always take mass transit.” Said Congressman’s district was part of Manhattan Island.)

              But out here on the West Coast, most if not all of the settlement boom took place after WW2, when cars & suburbia were dominant. Plus distances between towns & cities are greater once you get west of the Appalachians and Mississippi River. So unrefuelled range has always been more important the farther west you go.

            • jeffhre

              As you know, much of the growth in Southern Ca was supported by the Pacific Electric rail system. It was dismantled before the huge suburban cul-de-sac post war boom though.

        • Headless Unicorn Guy

          The standard Tesla Model S charger pulls 10 kW. If we also assume that 70% of the cars in New York are EVs, we get 85% of 70% of 5.1M cars @ 10 kW = 30,500 MW, all plugged in right on the dot of 18:00. Since we only have 931 MW of unused capacity at 18:00…

          8) Hello darkness, my old friend.

          Where I am, they’ve just put a new powerplant online — four big gas turbines running on natural gas, located in the middle of East Anaheim’s industrial district. Since gas turbines go to full power within seconds to minutes after startup, it’d be a natural for peak load operations, adding power to the grid as-needed.

          There was also talk of large trailer-sized modular turbine powerplants to come online for peak hours only, but I don’t think that got beyond design studies.

          • http://radical-moderation.blogspot.com/ TheRadicalModerate

            You can either go for lots more peaking capacity (which has moderate capital cost but extremely high operational cost–they’re inefficient single-cycle gas turbines, instead of the combined cycle plants), or you can go for more intermediate load capacity (which has higher capital cost but lower operational costs–they use the more efficient combined-cycle systems). Either way, it’s more expensive to add intermediate or peaking plants than it is to add base load.

        • Anonymouus Joule Thief

          Something to take into account…you did indeed bring the addition of solar into the equation, but forgot an important aspect of it’s implementation on residential housing. Solar panels provide shade, which in turn keeps housing cooler, reducing kW used for AC and in turn freeing up some capacity for charging you’re EV.

          Also to consider is since 70% market penetration won’t happen over night, people will be buying more efficient appliances, more efficient LED lighting, presumably anticipating somewhat higher usage for EV when sizing their solar PV systems (presumably solar installers will steer them towards this) and while there might be some dimming, I don’t think that it will be ” hello darkness” per se.

          • http://radical-moderation.blogspot.com/ TheRadicalModerate

            I think this is all doable, but I’m still skeptical it can be done without active load management by the utilities, i.e., a smart grid.

            There are basically three ways to manage the load spike that occurs when everybody plugs in their car as they come home:

            1) Everybody has enough battery capacity at home to dump some significant fraction of the accumulated accumulated charge into the car. Note that a cloudy day can mess this up. This is also way, way expensive for the near term.

            2) Over-the-top smart (i.e., not integrated directly with the utility) chargers, which can talk back to the mothership at Tesla, GM, Nissan, etc. to spread the load over the night. I can’t really tell if this can solve the problem or not.

            First, the mothership has to have fine-grained geoloc and an intimate knowledge of the utility layout in order to be effective in the load distribution. That’s doable, and may turn out to be a lot cheaper (and safer) than a smart grid where the utility is controlling the consmers’ devices.

            Second, however, is more problematic: Consumers are notoriously bad at any sort of sophisticated setup, and their motivations aren’t necessarily aligned with the goal of reducing peak load. What they want is a fully charged car ASAP, just because they want to be able to make an emergency trip or leave earlier in the morning. So first you have to give them a better motivation (steep discounts on off-peak power will certainly help), then you have to allay their nighttime range anxiety (i.e., that they have enough juice to go to the hospital or to help Grandma when she’s fallen and can’t get up), and then you have to get them to set the charging schedule properly.

            3) Go to a smart grid, where the utility doesn’t give you a choice about your motivation and your range anxiety. This is expensive for the utility and has a variety of safety and security problems.

            Bottom line is going to be that if we went to 70% EVs over a very short time span (say, ten years), we’d be in trouble. And even if we get there over a longer time span, we’re going to need somewhat more intermediate capacity (since the total charging load would require running the current grid at near peak capacity all night, which is expensive), and a lot more peak capacity (for cloudy days), and we’re going to need some form of load control that works reliably.

            This is all doable. My complaint (up above about 3 levels now), is that it’s not doable with the existing grid in the near-term.

    • Lukas Abegg

      I’m not an expert at all, but I’ve read that the Tesla Powerwall has
      some sort of “smart grid” features built in (mainly software, I guess?). Seems
      that Tesla is about to tackle the grid problem as well.

      (Sauce: http://techcrunch.com/2015/04/30/tesla-powerwall-home-battery/#.3xj8hs:8zBT)

      • http://radical-moderation.blogspot.com/ TheRadicalModerate

        I don’t think the problem is the Powerwall; it’s the EV charger. The Powerwall doesn’t have enough capacity to charge the EV (10 kWh vs. 60 kWh for the standard models), so at best it can shift the evening charging peak a couple of hours–which definitely helps, but doesn’t solve the problem.

        On the other hand, as the residential battery capacity approaches the EV capacity, and the solar capacity is large enough to charge the residential battery completely over the peak sun hours, then things start to change pretty substantially. You’ve still got problems with cloudy days and needing a lot more peak capacity in the grid (which is expensive to add), but the whole system hangs together pretty well.

  • Ian Freud

    Counterpoint: Tesla still haven’t overcome the problem of energy density – which is the *real* reason EVs haven’t yet gained traction: https://scottlocklin.wordpress.com/2012/07/09/energy-storage-and-green-technologies/

    In short, a kilo of petrol or diesel contains an order more magnitude of energy than a kilo of batteries. At the moment, being able to build lots more batteries in a “Gigafactory” doesn’t make batteries any better as a means of transporting energy.

    None of this is to say that EVs aren’t the future – they are – but the big section in the post dealing with “why EVs haven’t taken off” misses some pretty critical stuff that Tesla hasn’t come any closer than anyone else to solving.

    • Ian Freud

      And on a related note, energy transportation is the other part of the problem. A petrol car carries its energy with it: transporting energy from a power plant to a remote location loses a *lot* of power along the way, making it less efficient to do so. As cost is inextricably bound up with efficiency, these are big deals when trying to transition to EVs. Tesla at the moment is using licensed battery technology from other people (I believe Samsung) so strip away the marketing and the company hasn’t solved these problems. I hope they do, but there are big problems which are bound to inextricable physical laws that haven’t as yet been cracked.

      • jeffhre

        Panasonic.

      • Jeff

        But how about the efficiency lost getting petrol to the refinery and through the refinery process and then to the gas station?

      • Andre Needham

        “transporting energy from a power plant to a remote location loses a *lot* of power along the way, making it less efficient to do so” is not a true statement. Electricity transmission losses are measured in the single digits. From US EIA data, transmission losses are under 7%.

    • Jeff

      But…who cares? Right now a car can get how many miles per tank? 300? 400? 500? The Tesla gets 265 and the Roadster gets 350. There’s a quote in the post about Musk saying they could make cars with 500 mile ranges right now but the price would be too high. Presumably, Gigafactory = lower price of batteries = future 500 mile-range Teslas. So if the range of a gas car and EV are the same, who cares about energy density?

      • Headless Unicorn Guy

        As long as you don’t have to sit around for six hours charging.

        A few times a year, I have reason to drive from LA area to SF area. 400 miles/600km, usually with one fill-up (10 minutes max) around the halfway point. (Was able to do it on one tank until my transmission blew & the replacement’s 5th was geared differently, increasing my high-speed cruise fuel consumption by 5-10%.) Total trip time (including meal stops), six-eight hours.

        Under non-Tesla EVs and assuming I-5, I’d have to stop and recharge (six-eight hours) at Grapevine, stop and recharge (six-eight hours) at Kettleman, stop and recharge (six-eight hours) at Santa Nella (where the Gilroy Cutoff cuts off of I-5), then after all those recharge stops (over a couple days) finally pull into my destination. Then the same four-step going back.

        With a Tesla (which I can’t afford), I’d have only one stop-and-recharge (half an hour) around Kettleman.

  • Mark Monnin

    Just FYI: “The Wright Brothers’ 12 second, 120-foot-high flight” seems to be wrong. Wikipedia says “The first flight, by Orville at 10:35 am, of 120 feet (37 m) in 12 seconds, at a speed of only 6.8 miles per hour (10.9 km/h) over the ground, was recorded in a famous photograph.[35] The next two flights covered approximately 175 and 200 feet (53 and 61 m), by Wilbur and Orville respectively. Their altitude was about 10 feet (3.0 m) above the ground.” 120 feet in 12 seconds = 10 feet per second = 6.8 miles per hour

    • Ryder

      Ya, the 120′ was the *distance* of the flight… good catch

    • Reint Harkink

      Not the Wright Brothers but Gustave Whitehead was the first to fly an airplane; see “http://www.flyingmag.com/pilots-places/pilots-adventures-more/wright-brothers-not-first-fly”

      It was in the summer of 1901 that
      Whitehead flew his airplane, which he called the Condor. In the early
      hours of 14 August 1901, the Condor propelled itself along the darkened
      streets of Bridgeport, Connecticut, with Whitehead, his staff and an
      invited guest in attendance. In the still air of dawn, the Condor’s
      wings were unfolded and it took off from open land at Fairfield, 15
      miles from the city, and performed two demonstration sorties. The second
      was estimated as having covered 1½ miles at a height of 50 feet, during
      which slight turns in both directions were demonstrated.” The length of
      flight and altitude reached make the Wright’s first powered foray pale
      in comparison.
      Read more at http://www.flyingmag.com/pilots-places/pilots-adventures-more/wright-brothers-not-first-fly#9dUq5mwmWSG5KkYR.99

    • Ryder

      I believe that the general rule for those batteries is ~10 years. It’s a consumable, like gasoline… just that it needs to be “refilled” less often, but at much higher costs.

      • jeffhre

        Not a consumable – but an expensive specialty energy container which is expected to have over 75% of it’s original capacity after about ten years.

        • Ryder

          Overly specialized again, I see. Everyone knows WHAT a battery is… but I’m discussing HOW to view it in terms of economic ramification. The cost of their replacement should be “amortized” in cost to operate (generally per mile), just as gas, oil etc, are consumables in standard cars… Then of course add tires, etc.

          Anything intended to be used then replaced as part of normal operation is automatically a consumable.

          • jeffhre

            Yes I agree, durables are often amortized. That is one more way they differ from consumables.

            Not sure what defining a battery willy nilly as a consumable has to do with you being overly specialized. Unless you are one of the 92% of engineering majors who did not choose general engineering. And you do not work in a general engineering position.

            Then of course you may have designed and engineered your own glass house. Not germane to the issue again, but by now the pattern is expected.

            • Ryder

              It was a comment about you being overspecialized… making a point that while trivially true, did not address what was said.

  • Jay Kay

    I’m going to finally post my comment on this… First a disclaimer: I am a car guy, watch(ed) top gear, raced my Porsche 944 Turbo on race tracks, and drive for fun.

    That being said, the electric car is going to save the gas-burner.

    Just like the car save the horse.

    Meaning a gas-powered car, like a sailboat or a horse, will be enjoyed for the joy of the thing… the noise, ect.

    I JUST test drove a Tesla. I even took a test drive of a Roadster in Colorado up a canyon road a “few” years ago.

    Same impression… at first it was weird, then it was magical. The acceleration more linear than my BMW. Handling better.
    Steering even better.
    The design and looks are just better.
    Oh, and the accelerator pedal is a Fast-Foward button…
    …you can’t call it a throttle anymore because you are not throttling (or choking) the air off to an engine that is burning (exploding) stuff.

    Then we come to the price…
    well, ouch.
    ($100K for a 690+hp sedan that rivals the likes from Porsche, Maserati, and Aston Martin, well OK, that makes sense… $85K for a 420hp M5 beater. OK… if you can spend that type of coin)

    The point of this (and the post in general) is if you don’t build something people will want, why will they buy it?
    It is a VERY good car, with low maintenance, great design, and if you build a mini hydro plant, have solar cells on your home or a turbine, then it really is a no-brainer, assuming you can afford the thing.
    And yes it is a good car. Now just make more money so you can go buy it.

      Re: the popularity of older tech: A similar thing happened with the wristwatch. When cheap, digital watches came on the scene… the traditional art of producing mechanical watches was threatened… some predicted their demise… but they are terrifically popular now… commanding insane price tags.

      My favorite coffee grinder is about 100 years old… made of heavy cast metal parts. It produces a grind far superior to any you will find from a department store grinder. I’ll never part with it, until I die… then my son gets it

  • JEL50

    Why not tackle nuclear power as a source of clean energy vs. transportation? This article is amazing, but it jumps straight into transportation without mentioning in more detail the one power source we have today (emphasis on today) that can achieve your goals (moving us towards emissions free energy)?

    Why not go into detail and fact finding about nuclear energy as well? A lot of scientists and smart people would argue that: a. it works today and does not need a ton of new R&D to make it scalable; b. politics (and not safety concerns) prevent capital from financing new supply; c. fear mongering keep this issue out of the mainstream discourse

    More importantly, if the French can handle nuclear power, I am dead certain the liberators of Europe can handle nuclear power….

    • lolcopter

      Latest reactor build by Areva (the French company who builds nuclear plants) was started in 2005, will be ready in 2018-2020 and will costs € 8.5 billion, just to build it (look at Olkiluoto 3)
      Other EPR3+ reactor, same story: Flamanville 3 (by EDF, 85 % owned by the French state), started in 2007, not yet finished,
      China, Germany, Japan, and India are actually producing more power from renewable sources than from Uranium. Germany and Switzerland are dismissing their nuclear reactors, in Austria they are just banned, Italy has stopped its plan to build nuclear reactors and, like Spain and Germany, 20~25 % of the electricity is generated from renewable sources.
      I don’t think we are going to see a “nuclear renaissance”.
      By the way, most of Europe was liberated by URSS, UK and other local forces.

    • jeffhre

      Safety concerns are not slowing nuclear – price is.

    • Kyle MacDonald

      Nuclear power works great for France because it’s easy to sell all that excess generation capacity at low rates to their neighbors. (It’s hard to shut off nuclear power once it starts) Lots of $ losses for France in all that nuclear generation that they’re able to mask in creative accounting.

  • Jeff

    I think the Y-axis scales on the graphs in “Carbon Dioxide Variations” are offensively misleading. The difference between the X-axis horizontal an 200 is nowhere near the distance from 200 to 400. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temperature_record#/media/File:EPICA_temperature_plot.svg

  • David Gluss

    N.B. you mentioned in note 3 that a calorie is about 4 joules. Many people (dieters) think of a calorie as the thing that a carrot has 25 of…but that is a kilo-calorie…a carrot has 25000 calories.

    Another contributing factor to the immediate sluggishness of electric car sales is insurance. If you buy a Leaf, say, the insurance company will now charge you for two cars: the one you use for long trips, and the Leaf…as if you could drive both at once. And, then, taxes on both…more defensible I suppose because you do OWN them both at the same time. So the electric car has to completely replace the gasoline version at once.

  • Matt Menezes

    What’s probably the biggest issue I see with EV’s is there’s no charging infrastructure if you live in an apartment building and have to park in a parking lot. Property management companies would have to put plugs in certain spots, and that costs money.

    The only other way to own an EV and live in an apt is to charge it at the supercharging station once a week, and that would probably get old. Other than that, I’m really looking forward to the Model 3…

    • fliptherain

      I agree. This is one of my main concerns. I have a garage but there’s absolutely NO ROOM in there for my future EV. I’m sure they’ll figure out a way around this once EVs get more popular.

      • Matt Menezes

        Once EV’s are more prevalent, I’d assume parking garages would get savvy and have special EV spots where you can park you car and charge it. You’d pay for parking and any power consumed. This way, if you can’t charge it overnight at your house, you can charge it during the day while at work… 😀

      • jeffhre

        ” have a garage but there’s absolutely NO ROOM in there for my future EV. I’m sure they’ll figure out a way around this…”

        EBAY?

    • Kyle MacDonald

      This is a non-issue. Power outlets exist in cold climates for block heaters already and are super cheap to install. Your building will install outlets – or you can chose to live in a building with outlets. You can also just use an extension cord.

      • Matt Menezes

        I don’t know where you live, but any property management company I’ve ever lived under would flip out if I had extension cables running 100 meters out into a parking lot. I understand what you are saying about choosing to live in a building with EV chargers, but that’s not always practical. I’m sure over time property management companies will catch up, but for now I wouldn’t hold me breath.

        The bottom line is there needs to be a small charging station at the head of certain spots so people with EV’s can park there and charge overnight. If electric costs are an issue, put a credit card swipe and NFC payment mechanism so any power consumed is paid for.

        Honestly, in urban or semi-urban areas where apartments and condos are prevalent, it may be worthwhile opening special, privately funded parking garages or parking lots for EV’s where you can park your car charge it during the day while at work and/or over night while sleeping. If you account for the cost of parking in a city (~$200/mo. give or take), adding another $20-40 a month (and maybe $200 down up front to cover half the cost of an EV charging station) to be able to charge and EV would be awesome. It might be a couple of blocks away, but at least it’d circumvent property management companies who tend to lag behind the times…

  • Thomas

    As always nice and interesting post, but Tim, you seem a little bit too excited about Elon Musk. Climate change is a given, and we certainly need renewable energy, BUT this is not necessarily an argument against gas cars. The problem to be solved is storing the energy, and batteries are a very ineffective way of storing energy. Liquid fuel, e.g. bioethanol seems to be a much more effective method of storing energy than batteries ever will be. To store the energy of 50 liters of fuel you need a 400kg battery which you need to drive around all the time, which costs valuable recources and energy to built. What if fuel is made using renewable energy/carbon neutral sources? It would be interesting to compares these alternatives rather than assuming gas cars must run on fossile fuels. Gas cars running on biofuels or fuels synthetized using renewable energies may be the cheaper and possibly environmentally more friendly alternative. I don’t know, but it may be worth to think about it.

    • tu_79

      Yeah, I think the same. Problem is, that we need to reduce drastically the world population before attempting biofuels, or it will cause major famines in poor countries. It will be best achieved, in my opinion, when most countries get developed and people control its growth willingly. This will take decades at best, so biofuels are not the next step in sustainability.

    • Bassie

      Biofuels are a possibility but like tu_79 mentioned they also have downsides.
      Personally I don’t believe they will be a viable long term solution. While it is true that they have a higher energy density than most batteries (I remember a paper about high density energy storage with a new type of battery but can’t seem to find it atm) their production is quite problematic. Compared to for example solar panels plants are not very efficient a capturing and converting solar energy.
      Even the most efficient energy crops strugle to convert more than 1% of the solar energy they recieve whereas modern solar panels have an effiency of about 10%, add to this the fact that not all parts of the crop are usable for biofuels and the percentage of energy lost in converting the usable parts in to biofuels and you’ll be lucky to get 1/20 of the energy solar panels could produce given the same area.
      Ofcourse growing plants might be more environmentally friendly than producing batteries and solar panels but there are other things to consider.
      Like tu_79 mentioned competition with human food consumption could become a real issue. Given the growing world population and increased meat consumption (also a big problem) argricultural systems are already under quite some stress. It’s not like we’ll be running out of room to farm but we might run out of available high quality farming land (good soil, climate, water availability). We could ofcourse opt to use the better soils for food production and only use less suitable ones for fuel production but this would further decrease the fuel yield/acre.
      A last point in favor of electric propulsion vs biofuels is the increasing yield of solar cells (and possibly other means of producing electricity) whereas we haven’t yet managed to increase to efficiency of photosynthesis meaningfully and have already reached the limit on how much we can increase harvest index.
      Maybe one day we can improve the efficiency of biofuels to a point where they would surpass alternatives but nowadays I believe we’re better of using farmland to try and sustain an ever growing population.

      • CW_87

        I fully agree with your post. Additionally, we should mention the problem ZlatkoK mentions in another post: burning fuels (no matter if they are fossil or bio) emits lots of toxic substances (small particles, nitrogen oxides, …). This is not the case for electric cars with batteries.

  • Ashley Wilsey

    1. I’m alarmed at how long it took me to read this, largely because I kept having to walk away and think about things.

    2. Thank you.

    3. No, really, THANK YOU. I’ve been on the fence about electric cars for … well, as long as they’ve been a topic, but this served to clear a bunch of things up for me (and get me thinking about other parts of the argument). Specifically, that we’re attacking energy issues from six different angles when we could be taking a more concerted approach — after all, if we can work toward cars that can run on electricity while we also work toward more power generation from renewable resources as well, we could actually get somewhere. It’s a straight-line answer to ease our oil dependency (which, after all, will some day no longer be feasible). Instead, we’ve got research into for hydrogen cars while also shooting for solar power and all sorts of different ways to heat our houses… We lack focus. While multiple areas of research isn’t necessarily a bad thing, when the opposition to change is SO solid it seems like a rifle approach would be better than a shotgun approach.

    4. I feel like a diagram would best explain my response there but I don’t think I can manage that.

    5. Also, thanks for including the quote from Christie Nicholson. I laughed for an inappropriately long time when I hit that one in the biography. It was fun to relive.

    6. Good luck with a SpaceX?/Mars? post. I’m looking forward to it!

  • ZlatkoK

    Tim, really an impressive article, like usually great approach to a complex and wide topic. But this time I’ve been even more interested than before, because it very important for my work. As I work in the European Commission, particularly on air quality and emissions of pollutants from cars.

    This aspect is sometimes overlooked in the green cars/transport debate. Here the gains by using electric vehicle are even bigger that for greenhouse gases. Every single electric car that replaces one with a combustion engine, directly influences health of our citizens (especially in cities). Because no cancerogenic small particles are emitted (PMs) as well as really unhealthy nitrogen oxides (so called NOx). In Europe this is way more pronounced than in the US, because of high dieselisation rates (diesels are actually much worse than petrols, not to mention electric vehicles).

    Raising of awareness about smog/health problems and its solution through use of electric cars could be more emphasized by electric car manufacturers.

    let me leave just these two links:

    WHO determining exhaust (particularly diesel) cancerogenic
    http://www.lung.org/associations/charters/northeast/programs/msb/news-archive/WHO_Diesel_Causes_Cancer.html

    original study
    http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lanonc/article/PIIS1470-2045%2812%2970280-2/fulltext

    performance of latest diesels in EU
    http://www.theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/ICCT_PEMS-study_diesel-cars_20141010.pdf

Makes me wonder if we didn’t invent global warming, because no one was listening to stop the polluting of the planet. I am looking forward to when we tie climate change to the massive waste island floating in the pacific.

      • Ryder

        Carbon does not (raise the temp of the earth). Carbon dioxide does. Don’t mean to nitpick, but it’s not a small distinction.

    • Yugo Reventlov

      You know, I have a company car. I was refused a Prius because it had to be a diesel.

      The reason?

      There is less tax on Diesel fuel compared to Petrol, so all companies are leasing Diesel cars.

      For the same reason, Diesel cars are more popular on the second hand market and thus have a better re-sale value for companies.

        Let me leave another link
        http://www.theicct.org/sites/default/files/publications/ICCT_LaboratoryToRoad_2014_Report_English.pdf

        Difference between official and real fuel consumption is exploding (that’s why I wrote artificial CO2 values)…

    Is the electrical grid ready for the duty of charge millions of cars at homes?

    Or everyone should install solar/eolic to generate the extra power?

    • Alasdair Shepherd

      I take it you didn’t read the article, then.
      ”
      Myth: EVs are a huge burden on the electric grid.

      Actually: The grid is sized for the worst second of the worst day of the worst year—so there’s usually a lot of excess capacity. You could replace 70% of US gas car miles with EV miles with no changes to the grid. That percentage will also grow even higher as more homes get their power from solar panels.
      ”

      Also yes. Everyone should be powered by renewables eventually.

  • dasxt

    2 questions:
    1) If animals were stuck underground and transformed into fossil fuels instead of decomposing, does that mean that we experienced a period of lowering CO2 levels during the time when these fossil fuels were being formed hundreds of millions of years ago?

    2) To increase the amount of CO2 in the air means we are disturbing the ideal equilibrium of CO2 in the air vs. in the ground. Given that the carbon in the world system is constant (just existing in different states and forms), does this mean that ideally we should have more carbon existing in things instead of in the air? I guess that explains why carbon capture and storage technologies exist although it does seem a waste to place carbon artificially underground instead of trying to place this carbon in useful forms such as plants.

    • Ryder

      It is my understanding that most plant life evolved in periods of significantly higher atmospheric CO2… so plants/trees today are typically CO2 starved.

      CO2 levels under the canopy in rain forests is much higher than anywhere else… the gas being evolved locally through old growth decay. Rain forests are pretty damned green and happy.

      Food growers know this, and some have taken to covering certain crops and adding CO2 to help the plants grow.

      The purely political move to re-categorize CO2 as a “pollutant” (it would actually make MORE sense to categorize oxygen as a pollutant), is really a horrifically backward notion. So when it comes to a notion of CO2 equilibrium… I don’t know how you select it. What’s best for the plants? Since we depend on them, quite directly, for other forms of life, I tend to side with the plants on this.

      How ironic that the “green” movement, depicted with a leaf, has centered on selling this life giving gas for those very same leaves, CO2, as “pollution”.

      • Headless Unicorn Guy

        Problem is, Green(TM) and its current high-profile incarnation of Global Warming(TM) has become a Fundamentalist Religion on both sides, complete with Church Lady Superiority Dance and Die, Infidels.

        It’s like a hyped version of the “METRIC NOW!” and “STOP METRIC MADNESS!” fundamentalists in the Seventies when there was talk of the USA going metric. True Believers rallied on both sides, battle lines were drawn, Jihads were declared against The Infidels, and they both ended up cancelling each other out.

    • Headless Unicorn Guy

      Has anyone else heard speculation that some petroleum is produced not by decaying dinosaurs (such as the old Sinclair Oil commercials) but by deep-earth extremophile bacteria? This would make oil a renewable resource, but if the renewal rate is well below the extraction rate, it doesn’t make all that much short-term difference.

      • Yugo Reventlov

        Is there any research indicating in this direction, or are you in fact just speculating?

  • Jan Sibo

    Good article, but:

    you wrote: “I’m pretty convinced that the Model S is the best expensive car ever made. In its first year, its sales blew away its well-known direct competitors—the S-Class Mercedes, BMW 7-Series, the Lexus LS, and the Audi A8—and it’s been in the lead ever since.”

    [citation needed]

    in its first year (2012), tesla sold a total of 2.650 Model S (source: insideevs.com). Benz sold SIXTY-FIVE THOUSAND s-classes in 2012 (source: daimler media).

    this just leaves an overall bad taste in my mouth, considering the rest of the article is pretty good. also, why did you leave out nuclear power?

      Tim is correct if by “its first year” he means it’s first FULL year (2013) and if the comparison is like-to-like, i.e. American sales only. So I would conclude that Tim was right on this.

  • Ben

    I just read the 2-part Artificial Intelligence series and the 2-part Musk/Tesla series back-to-back, which is raising a serious question for me – if, to an extremely high likelihood, AI is going to utterly transform humanity over the next 40-85 years, why bother worrying about the sort of issues raised in this post?

    That’s a super fatalistic / depressing viewpoint, but do our advancements in combatting global warming actually matter in the vast scheme of things, given that when the super-advanced AI comes along, it will be able to easily solve these issues (or it will extinguish humanity and there’ll be no one to worry about it)? There are still worthwhile issues to fight for if you take this viewpoint – mostly around reducing suffering or increasing pleasure / convenience TODAY – but why bother fighting too heavily for the future of planet Earth when it’s going to be resolved one way or another before global warming can go too far?

    • Headless Unicorn Guy

      Ben, that sounds like a secularization of the Christianese “It’s All Gonna Burn (so why bother)”. I got messed up enough by that during the heyday of Hal Lindsay in the Seventies, and my caveat is the same as to the Left Behinders:

      When The World Ends Tomorrow and It’s All Gonna Burn, you have no future. Don’t expect long-range planning or daring great things. But even when you have no future, The Future has a way of happening anyway whether you’re involved or not — and you WILL find yourself Left Behind. (Just not in the way you think.)

    • Eric Mauk

      Battery powered vehicles can but it will use a ton of battery. They have 400+ horsepower engines, but you will pay for the power with battery life.

      • Headless Unicorn Guy

        There’s also the problem that in cold climates using the heater on an EV can cut its range in half or worse. Fuel-burners run their heaters on the bleed heat from the engine cooling system.

        What this means is we’ll probably see EVs taking over bit by bit, starting in and working from warmer climates with cleaner (light blue on the map) utility emissions. Urban areas (which require less daily driving) would also be earlier adopters, but a lot of the USA’s older urban areas are in snow country.

        • http://www.jou.no Jon Ole Ueland

          Good point about the heaters – but not entirely true; Nissan f.ex uses heat-pumps similar to those used in homes to heat up their Leafs (http://www.nissan-global.com/EN/TECHNOLOGY/OVERVIEW/heat_pump_cabin_heater.html)

  • Fred

    Good and useful article. A bit long and sometimes repetitive, but on the other hand, eye-opening. Maybe a little too admirative towards Musk, but I’m picky

    There’s just one thing that really bothers me: you’re quite wrong about Darwin’s theory and how evolution works.
    – “[…] and over time, the genetics of the species will react to the pressure by changing in order to optimize to the new environment”.
    There’s no such thing as “genetics will react”, and “in order” is more like “randomly” (actually it’s a bit more complicated, but, you know, I’m not a good blogger/writer!).

    However, you seem to be good at diving in a complex topic for a few weeks, and then come back to the world with a good, funny, well-sourced and consistent post. This subject could be fun ! Or how about a “Darwinists vs Creationists” post ? Just planting a seed…

    (If i made mistakes, sorry for my english, not my native language)

    • Ae

      The don’t literally react, you’re right, but it’s a useful metaphor for explaining the interaction

      • jeffhre

        Right. Could be a decent but loose metaphor for phenotype and adaptation, but not to be taken literally. I think it works well enough in this context.

  • André Baptista

    According to the studies compiled here:

    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global-warming_potential

    Methane has a GWP (Global Warming Potential), many, many, many times greater than that of Carbon Dioxide.
    Are we fighting against the wrong enemy? Should we put all this effort on methane instead of CO2?

    PS. Just a non-specialist question. I’m really amateur in this subject.

    • David McWilliams

      If I remember correctly, I think Methane dissipates faster, while CO2 is around until it’s absorbed by photosynthesis?

      • Rikaishi Rikashi

        https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atmospheric_methane#Emissions_accounting_of_methane

        Sounds about right. We don’t really understand the full methane cycle yet. What we can say for sure is that most of our emissions are quickly removed from the atmosphere, but the overall concentration of methane is still increasing slowly and that is a concern.

    • Eric O’Reilly

      neither really matter. You see the energy comes from the sun, then is filtered by the EM field of the planet, then filtered or reflected by the atmosphere … then the energy that actually makes it to the ground is either reflected or absorbed. Solids have the ability to retain more energy than gas or liquids, but they reflect more than they hold. Liquids like water the energy can penetrate many feet and the energy can be absorbed verses reflected. That said the oceans are the next biggest thing that determines the retained heat on the planet. The gases in the atmosphere are such a tiny ridiculously small number that it becomes irrelevant. There are a lot of comments discussing this below.

      • Rikaishi Rikashi

        The “EM field of the planet” can only deflect charged particles. Not visible light and infrared radiation.

        What you’ve waved off as “filtered by the atmosphere” is the problem at hand, as “filtered” in this case is another way of saying “absorbed”. CO2 and methane act like little radiators within the atmosphere, absorbing energy which would normally be reflected out in to space and heating up the atmosphere around them. Then the hotter atmosphere transfers that heat to the oceans, leading to a buildup of heat within the whole system.

        Our oceans have been in an unusually long La Nina (which stores heat in the oceans) period for the last decade which has kept the global average temperature down, but that appears to be ending for now and we’re heading in to an El Nino where the oceans release more energy in to the atmosphere.

        • Eric O’Reilly

          I am in the process now of setting up an experiment that will measure regular air, heavy concentration of CO2 air, water, rocks, and sand all in different glass mason jars. When I have completed the experiment I will post it on youtube. Maybe then we will finally recognize a gas doesn’t have the necessary mass to absorb enough energy to move the temperature of an entire planet.

          • Rikaishi Rikashi

            Don’t forget to insulate the jars within a perfect vacuum and observe them for an appropriate period of time given the rate of change of the system you are comparing them to.

            Half a century should be enough. Have fun.

  • Ella

    A bunch of ideas…
    How long will the changeover from gas car to EVs take? From when the Ford Motor company was founded in 1903, to when the majority of people put their horses out to pasture and their carts in the shed, that was a good few years. My father remembers travelling around by horse and cart, growing up in the 60’s and 70’s in rural New Zealand. Partly because they were broke, and partly because my grandfather loved his horses. But then it was still fairly normal to do that- nearly 70 years and the good old trap was still going fairly strong. I’ll bet there will be people in the future like my grandad, still driving their gas card around. Although horses don’t really have the same emission problems as your gas powered car. (A lot of people in isolated regions still use horses a lot for transport, but that’s kind of beside the point.)

    Somehow, though, I don’t think it will take that long. Technology is advancing much faster than it was a hundred years ago (do I rightly remember a post on here about that?), so in two years the Roadsters will probably have improved beyond recognition, compared to how much the Model T developed in the same amount of time. With the sheer amount of technological change making people more open to change, and the added pressure of GLOBAL WARMING, I doubt it will be 70 years before the majority of cars are EVs.

    The oil and motor engineering industry will be a bit like the harness-makers, the dray builders, the wheel-wrights. Either they will have to adapt and begin producing products suitable for EVs, or pretty much die out.

    Also, what about heavy vehicles, like trucks? I’m sure Musk has a plan for that too.

    It’ll be interesting to look back in 60 years and see how the world’s changed.

  • Prasad

    Hi Tim – I am from India, an old mechanical engineer who is working in the oil and gas industry. I really love reading all your posts – they are so full of detail and unbelievable, terribly exciting and intellectually stimulating information. My best wishes to you.

    When I was in my final semester in college about ~ 30 years ago, I was attending job interviews and one of them was for the Indian partner of the Leyland company of UK, which makes trucks and buses. There, they asked me the question why “does the steam engine” not have a gear box whereas an IC engine does? I gave an answer that the steam engine does not have to go over inclines or curves as much as an automobile, so it does not have have the need for varying torque output. He said that I was wrong, every propulsion machine needs the ability to vary its torque. He also said that in a steam engine it can be done by varying the quantity of steam admitted. He added that the IC is the “most least” suitable engine for a car as it produces constant torque but the problem has been circumvented by having a gear box + clutch. Moreover the efficiency of the IC engine cycle is extremely poor. With all these major shortcomings IC engines are still widely used as engineers have managed to circumvent all problems and present a workable and economical option.

    Now after all these years I read your article and its really an eye opener to see how auto companies and O&G business lobbyists have managed to take the world down a garden path of destruction though they may have been perfectly within the law to have done what they did and continue doing.

    I built a house near my place and I have done rain water harvesting in a big way as also solar water heating. I have also completely fitted LED/CFL light fittings in my house. Taking inspiration from articles such as these, grey water recycling, and solar power and buying and electric car are the next ones in my list. I have provided an electric socket in my garage to power my first electric car when ever it arrives. There is a small 2 seater called E 20 selling in my place which can do about 80 KM or so and costs about $ 8 K.

    The para that begins with
    ” A deeply-set, stagnant industry is like a country” just before the chapter 3 has got such a solid “connect” with events in my country that I was stunned. In one sentence it says what the reason is for so many things being wrong in my country despite 6 decades of independence. Things seem to be changing for the better now. I really hope Tesla sets up manufacturing in India – it’ll indeed be a great day for people like me..(hoping to have enough money to buy a Tesla car before I depart from this world!)

    Many thanks for a wonderful article. I hope to be able to read a lot more of your stuff in the times to come.

    Best regards
    P.Prasad Senji

    BTW – is there no way of stopping the “subscribe to WBW” pop up from appearing for people who have already subscribed?? I’m getting it all the time even though I have subscribed.

  • Matt Weed

    Tim, thank you. This has infected my brain and driven most of my conversations over the last few weeks. I do notice one piece of this puzzle left out though and wonder if you have it figured out already – the production cost of EVs as compared to traditional cars. I understand the premise of this movement being one that may not be 100% sunshine and rainbows now but will help us to ensure that we have some of each of those in the future. What I see as the most common push back to EVs, especially among people who get the above premise, is the environmental costs of solid-state battery production which you don’t bring up here. Help?

    • grendal

      Tim actually did address this point. If you don’t mind I’ll try to sum it up for him.
      Cars are made of stuff, usually metal, plastic, and some other things. Those things are shaped into a car like shape. Using a Tesla Model S and a similar gas car the BMW 7 series, you would find that they weigh almost the same amount. So while they seem like one is vastly different, they aren’t. That is also why the Model S is selling like crazy since it is a good value compared to a car that it competes against. The biggest extra cost is the battery pack which Tim explained in his reference to how expensive new technology is. The stuff in the battery isn’t vastly more expensive but it hasn’t been around before and the demand needed for all these cars is certainly new. So because it is new it is more expensive for now. The battery gigafactory should address the issue and that is why the Model 3 will start at $35,000.
      I hope that is helpful.

      • Matt Weed

        Thanks for the note. I wasn’t referring monetary costs, I was hoping to better understand the environmental costs associated with lithium battery production – extraction of materials, toxicity of chemical precursors, etc. It is mentioned that the final product – the cell – is not harmful and can actually be simply disposed of in the dump (though we of course prefer recycling!). I am alright with this assertion, but the production process involves many more chemicals that is likely somewhat proprietary. Just curious if anyone had any insights (with citations?) about this impact of solid-state battery production.

        • grendal

          A true environmental well to wheel analysis is practically impossible to do in a completely non-biased manner. Even every energy analysis that has been done that I have seen seems to miss one aspect or another which skews the data to the conclusion the person running the study was after in the first place. I think we would all agree that mining is a dirty business. Pumping oil out of the ground is equally dirty and has the added problem of being a liquid. There are ample examples of the huge environmental damage that has happened from oil spills. I doubt that lithium mining could even come close to that amount of damage. Lithium is also not a toxic element.
          The only real difference between a gas car and an electric car is the drive train. Since the “stuff” it is made of isn’t incredibly different, one has a little more steel and the other a little more lithium. It all comes down to how it is powered. Electricity versus burning a fossil fuel.
          It fundamentally comes down to the fact that oil is toxic and when burned is equally toxic and no longer usable. Therefore it is not sustainable.
          I am probably rambling, so I’ll apologize if I telling you something you already know.

  • Daniel Skroll

    Interesting article, way to go for EVs in general and Tesla in particular (even though I feel you might love Elon more than Berta…^^). I’m all in.

    But here is one thing bothering me while looking out of my apartment’s window, seeing BMW HQ on the horizon: I live in central Munich, that is no suburban home with a garage or even a guaranteed designated parking spot in front of my apartment building. At the moment, my car is 200m away from my door, parked in another street. Sometimes I have to walk for five minutes to get to my car, depending on where I find a spot to leave it in this densely populated city.

    Am I supposed to ask the people in the next building if someone wants to let me use their socket overnight? Or carry a 500m cable in order to use my socket at home…?

    Infrastructure is being built, yes, but as long as charging stations are rare, mostly non-public (located in parking lots and the like), incompatible or impractical to use, unfortunately, going electric simply makes no sense for city-dwellers and is only a viable option for people that live the suburban dream/nightmare…

    Especially, if car use is limited to only a few rides on an irregular basis as you mostly use public transport or a bicycle in daily life. I don’t care for my petrol car to stand there for a week until I need it the next time – not so sure though, if this is the same with an electric car (especially in cold winters) due to battery drain etc. always hoping to find one of the rare public spots where I can charge it when I drive it the next time…

    The industry (never mind how cool they are, Tesla is still a part of it) hasn’t come up with any convenient solutions for urbanites yet and leaves the responsibility on local authorities that have to come up with a system for a technology no-one knows which way it is actually going. It’s the classic egg&chicken story, but this doesn’t help me in my decision to go electric.

    Am I the only person in the world who wants to drive an EV but lives in an apartment building in a highly populated area?

    • Taylor Flanagan

      This is a good question. I’d like to see how Musk would go about fixing this. Personally I think the best way around it would be to have the ability to remove the battery and bring it inside for charging. Whether or not that’s a realistic possibility, I couldn’t say.

  • mickrrussom

    Hydrogen fuel cell tech is 1000x better than this carbon trading Tesla scam by scam artist Elon. His spacex is more expensive and failure prone and his Tesla without government credits would be a total and complete bankruptcy. Also coal fire plants charge Tesla, so its a polluter.

    Hydrogen Fuel Cell. H2 + O2 -> H20. Cant much better than that.

    But you Tesla S F85 guys just keep belching coalfire in the air and calling it green.

    • Peter Bull

      Did you actually read this article? How is even H2O emissions better than no emissions? You don’t get hydrogen without substantial energy input, so how is using coal-fired power to split water to get hydrogen better or more efficient than using coal-fired power to charge batteries directly?

      Let’s assume for a moment that both Tesla’s battery power and your hydrogen fuel are both generated by zero carbon solar power – as Tesla fully intends to do with all its charging stations.

      Technology 1- Electricity.
      Solar panels generate electric power direct to battery storage, which then charges device batteries.
      Outcome: Clean, efficient, simple, cheap, capable of distributed small scale power generation, safe.

      Technology 2 – Hydrogen fuel cell to create electricity.
      Solar panels power device to split water into O2 and highly explosive and flammable H2, H2 compressed and stored under pressure somehow, then distributed and sold to consumers, transferred to consumer device tank under pressure, H2 fed to fuel cell which burns it to produce electric power, releasing H20 to atmosphere.
      Outcome: Clean, but less efficient use of solar source power, complex process, expensive, centralised manufacture so controlled and distributed by oil companies or equivalent, unsafe – dangerously volatile (google Hindenberg Disaster).

      There is no argument for fuel cells that makes sense over direct solar generation of electric power – especially if the power generation process is localised as it easily can be, not centralised like gasoline/hydrogen manufacturing.

      • Anonymous

        Fuel cells make sense if you’re an oil company. Because most hydrogen comes from a) Electrolysis of Brine or b) Crude oil

    • jeffhre

      You are supporting either a 1)math challenged or 2)innumerate argument. Please pick one. Your argument works as well as 32.6 mj in a liter of gasoline, with “you can’t beat that.”

      The H2 advocates keep trying to reverse the H2 burning process and don’t even understand the energy inputs to get there. There is no H2 available on earth. You’d be more effective combining carbon dioxide, soot and water vapor – and catalyzing it in a fuel cell, while proclaiming you’ve found a non polluting way of making and using natural gas!

      “Hydrogen Fuel Cell. H2 + O2 -> H20. Cant much better than that.” I can do a lot better than that, sun light + PV to inverter + battery = propulsion. It gives 70% better energy use than CH4 conversion and + H2 + O2 + pumping to 1100 bar pressure + conversion by FC -> H20 and electricity.

    • gopher652003

      You can think of Hydrogen Fuel cells as a type of open cycle battery. Rather than keep all the reactants in the battery, it “exhausts” them after the reaction is complete. You then get electricity out of the reaction, which then powers an electric motor. They’re literally EVs with a different type of battery.

      The problem with hydrogen is that the fuel cycle is incredibly inefficient, even in theory. It is simply physically impossible (again, not just impractical, but physically impossible) to have an efficient hydrogen fuel cell. It cannot happen under the laws of physics. It *is* possible to have an efficient battery though, and we’ve not only developed them, but are already using them.

      Batteries end up being ~80% efficient, power plant to wheels. Hydrogen is about 55% efficient. Gasoline is about 25% efficient.

      So Hydrogen looses out in efficiency (by necessity it simply *can’t* win, because fuel cells suck), but what about energy density? Well… that’s stickier. Hydrogen is slightly, *slightly* more energy dense while in a fuel cell than batteries currently in production. But Hydrogen is already at its practical limit for density, while batteries are nowhere even close to theirs. Batteries are also improving their energy density at between 7 and 8% per year. They’ll pass Hydrogen’s energy density within 2 or 3 years.

      What about expense? Hydrogen loses, hands down. Super expensive.

      What about practicality? For battery tech to work we’ll need to spend ~10 billion dollars spreading a fast charging network around the world. Mostly in between cities for roadtrips, because everyone will just charge at home normally. For Hydrogen to work, we’ll need to build ~1 trillion dollars worth of filling stations around the world. Hydrogen looses, hands down.

      So, you might ask yourself, why in the F**K is anyone backing hydrogen? It all leads back to Toyota’s support for the technology. Everyone backing hydrogen is doing so because they’re planning to use Toyota tech. But why is Toyota backing hydrogen? Why, they’re doing it because the Japanese government wanted a “made in Japan” solution to alternative fueled vehicles. Something where – unlike with battery EVs – a majority of the patents could be held by Japanese companies, not by the “dirty Koreans”. (I don’t know if you’ve ever been to Japan – I have – but people in Japan are super, super, super racist. They hate everyone. But there is NO ONE that they hate and despise more than Koreans. It’s ridiculous, and it shouldn’t be that way, but it is (not universally of course! But by-and-large). Go to Japan. You will not be able to walk down the street without people yelling “gaijin” at you. It basically means “foreigner”, but the connotation of the word in Japan is similar to using the N-word in the US. Except everyone there does it, smirking (as much as Japanese people smirk, which isn’t much;)) while they do.)

      And that’s the reason why Hydrogen exists. Because the Japanese government is still in shock that Korea has surpassed them in so many areas, and they’re trying to use government funding to “pick winners and losers” in order to try and jumpstart stalled Japanese innovation. But that doesn’t make Hydrogen fuel cells a good technology for cars. It’s just stupid to use them in cars. Bad application for the technology, and everyone in the industry (including Toyota) knows it, they’re just not willing to stop the government gravy train;).

  • tanmayst

    Barring US, countries like India and Japan have MPG that is way greater, 45 to 50. One topic which should have been covered on this page is the exceptional quality of US consumer to depend on gas guzzling “SUV” monsters, and the required shift from “SUV” to more rational options like KEI cars.
    I am no way a supporter of oil industry or current auto industry. I just wanted an honest comparison of what direction are current gas engines progressing against the so loved “EV”. Japanese and Korean car makers are making exceptional advances in IC engine efficiency.

      It is less the efficiency of IC engines, and more the size of the vehicles that holds back American mi/g. It is hardly surprising that a Hyundai Accent gets a high mi/g than a monstrous H3. More mass = less efficiency, and usually less aerodynamics.
