      Did a lot of folks who once worked at Xerox, Kodak, DEC and the “Old GM” now work at Forbes?

  • Valkra

    I’m sold. When I get a full time job after graduation, I will definitely be on the market for a Tesla EV. I’m at the point where even if another company makes an EV that’s slightly better than a Tesla and they’re around the same price, I’ll still buy the Tesla. Elon Musk is my friggin’ hero!

  • raw915

    Way too little, way too late. The release of greenhouse gasses into the atmosphere is still accelerating, not decelerating as must be happening right now to avoid runaway global warming, desertification, melting of 7 million cubic miles of land-based ice, and rising of the oceans up to 216 feet. A thousand Elon Musks and Teslas won’t stop runaway global warming once it goes past the tipping point of releasing methane from the arctic tundra and the oceans. Climate scientists say that we may have a few decades at most before hell on earth.

    http://globalwarming.berrens.nl/globalwarming.htm

    • Ninjar DeHotfrm

      Right! We may not be able to keep under 2c degrees by the end of the century, even if everyone stopped driving cars right now today and everyone was using solar powered everything. The damage may have already been done.

  • raw915

    I looked at Tesla solar PV batteries. They are not cost effective for general home use, and their life is too short. They won’t sell to the general public in most areas. Of course right now it is a fad and Tesla can’t produce enough. As the Bloomberg article shows, Tesla is going after the commercial market. But Tesla may find their battery technology falling along the wayside in comparison to other advancing battery technologies. My bet is on molten battery technology such as coming out of MIT. http://www.ambri.com/

    http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-06/tesla-s-new-battery-doesn-t-work-that-well-with-solar

    • jeffhre

      The “general public” which you have referenced does not represent every person, household, and business globally. No product fits every universal need, of every single person, Tesla products included. And as you imply -“They won’t sell to the general public in most areas. Of course right now it is a fad and Tesla can’t produce enough.” – they will be sold in areas with addressable markets where they can be effective. (emphasis added)

      Flow batteries are also improving at an impressive rate.

  • Colm Hennessy

    I realise Tesls don’t advertise… But this was the finest “ad” I’ve ever encountered. I’m not doubting your probity – it’s clear you’re an impartial observer who has been won over to them.

    What I’m saying is, I’m won over too. Come the affordable Tesla, I’m buying one. Absolutely, unquestionably, I’m now buying one.

    Hope they can achieve what they are setting out to do with the Model 3…

  • Madame Blue

    I was just discussing the energy issue with 2 other people, and the conversation was becoming very pessimistic. I posted a link to Article #1, and said that I’m glad smart people are working on this, only to be told that money talks too loud, smart people are saying we’re all screwed, and greedy people just keep screwing us over. My response was, There’s one smart rich person giving me hope, and giving up isn’t a viable option.

    Thank you, Tim, for these articles. I look forward to reading #3 and #4, and would consider buying this series as a book if you decide to publish it.

  • LM285

    One thing I’m not sure about is the MPG figures. I’ve got a 2012 car in the UK, and I reset the MPG average counter each time I fill up. Usually it’s between 35-45 MPG over the course of a tank, and I’m told that in fact my car is pretty average. I wonder what the difference is – is it your cars tend to be less efficient (e.g. bigger), or your petrol (gas) is a different composition, or is there something else?

    • del

      US gallon is smaller than UK gallon. So the MPG figures are smaller.
      Its 1.2: 1 ratio or about 80%.

    • jeffhre

      “And in American terms, the range will be closer to 260 or 270 miles. That’s because the New European Driving Cycle, the test used to rate fuel economy across the pond, is a bit generous (and has been criticized as such). The Tesla Model S 85D, for example, has an EPA-rated range of 270 miles. In Europe, it’s rated for 328 miles, an 11 percent improvement for the exact same car.” From a “Wired” magazine discussion of a planned Audi Electric car.

  • Ugo

    sorry Tim, really toooo long.
    i just made it to the electric car market graph.

    anyway, three thing i wanted to add:
    1- the main reasons i see pushing us away from burning fossil fuel for electricity or cars is that we’ll need it for the plastic industry. we can find out fancy ways to move around and to light up the streets, but you’ll need crude to make plastic. and today’s world is made of plastic. then think that there are places where going to electric power will be very, very hard if not impossible at all, like airplanes.
    2- i’m not so convinced about the fact that cars produce more pollution than boats. there are a LOT of HUGE vessels in the world and for sure they have not the same pollution regulation cars have. has anybody have any data on this?
    3- the real problem with electric cars is not range, is time to refill. i can totally bear a 100 miles range if i can recharge in no more than 90 secs. battery swap is a tricky way: batteries do decay, what if i swap my new cars battery and end up with a semi-fucked battery?…

    (PS: don’t be fooled by car makers who say “we don’t believe ev will sell”. they perfectly know evs are the future and they already have their jockers in the sleeve. they’re only trying to keep up their actual values…)

    • Ninjar DeHotfrm

      It’s worth it…keep reading even if it takes you all week.

  • littlelightbulb

    So much to read. But completely worth it.

    Although, tbh, I would have read any nonsense combination of random words just for that drawing of bullshit. Priceless.

    If the EV revolution finally comes to fruition on the back of the Model 3 what will happen to all our gas cars? Maybe we should we should send the gas cars to mars to generate an atmosphere. Wouldnt it be more economical to design a way to convert gas cars into EVs instead of manufacturing entirely new EVs (if possible)?

  • Rob Armstrong

    4hrs straight through and would have read it even if it was longer. really exciting post. you even managed to lean me more towards the “climate change is all our fault camp”. too many people running around on social media typing in capitals that its SO OBVIOUS without actually explaining anything. also, can you please ask Mr Musk to make me an electric motorcycle?

  • Krishna Chetty

    After completing the article, I really understood the concept of building the trunk of the tree to sustain the leaves and branches of our knowledge tree. So, to get a complete grip on a topic, I have to go this deep now 😛 The business strategy of Tesla is really awesome. A true disruptor! But to see real change in the world, this revolution needs to spread everywhere, not just the US. And hats off to Elon Musk for trying to change the status quo!

  • Slav Dok

    Love the article, love the premise. I wish however you would have posted more about the rebuttal of the myths.

    I would very much love to spread the word in favour EVs, but I have a friend who fevereshly spits out “EV’s battery production impact on the environment is far greater than what a gas car would do in 10 years (which is apparently the lifetime of those batteries)”.

    Please, give me some ammunition to fight that.

    • http://wellspringfoam.blogspot.com/ Mate Sršen

      Ten years is NOT the lifetime of the batteries. This has been massively misconstrued. Ten years is how long it will take the batteries to noticeably lose capacity (!!!). And ‘noticeably’ is apparently about 10-20%:
      http://www.csmonitor.com/Business/In-Gear/2015/0219/How-much-will-Tesla-Model-S-battery-life-decrease-over-time
      So: after ten years, with proper care, it is estimated that the Model S battery pack can have about 90% of its original capacity.
      This is not to say that making the batteries in the first place has a huge environmental impact – I’m just not familiar with it.

  • darryl

    Late to the game here as usual. Just curious if they are working on an EV semi at all? Seems like it could make sense once battery costs come down.

    -d

  • John Fishburn

    David Roberts says you need to get more engaged with politics: http://www.vox.com/2015/8/27/9214015/tech-nerds-politics
